article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: Advocacy groups, health care centers and a major Texas insurer have scheduled several weekend events and staffed 24-hour call centers ahead of a Monday deadline to get people enrolled in a health insurance plan to take effect Jan. 1.  To deal with an expected rush, organizations and agencies including the Harris Health System, the League of United Latin American Citizens, the city of Houston and local churches will hold enrollment fairs and sign-up events Saturday and Sunday to accommodate uninsured people locally.  Nationwide, more than 2.5 million people applied for coverage between Nov. 15 and Dec. 5 using the federal health insurance marketplace website, healthcare.gov, according to the most recent data available from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.  Claudia Lozano, a Houston field officer for the national insurance advocacy group Enroll America, already knows more than 20 people are expected Saturday to receive enrollment help at the League of United Latin American Citizens office on the city's southwest side.  [...] the Houston Department of Health and Human Services' call center is answering people's questions and scheduling enrollment appointments for in-person application assistance for residents in Houston and its 12 surrounding counties.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lora Hines

og.title: Obamacare 2015: First coverage deadline approaches
